Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation of Native Hawaiians for Engineering Faculty Careers

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is focused on developing an integrated educational model that will motivate Native Hawaiian graduate students to seek academic careers. Native Hawaiians are significantly underrepresented in the STEM workforce, even more so that other racial and ethnic minorities. Native Hawaiians comprise 23% of the state's population, but only 12.8% of the student body and 3.8% of the faculty. More compelling is that of the 1500+ STEM faculty, only 4 are Native Hawaiian. To encourage more Native Hawaiian students to pursue engineering and other STEM fields, role models have a highly visible role, particularly within the educational environment. A diverse faculty provides a rich learning experience for the student as well as significantly enhancing the research enterprise through diversity of thoughts and ideas.

This project will gather information from the Native Hawaiian students and community, utilizing surveys and interviews to research and understand why students are not likely to pursue engineering graduate studies. Using the results, the team will develop a model to provide teaching and research experiences as a pathway to an academic career. The research projects will be focused on the Pacific region, thus enhancing their relevance to the students. A mentoring program will be implemented utilizing engineering faculty and a virtual network that evolves from the establishment of a national Society for Native Hawaiians Engineers. The intellectual merit of this activity is the identification of what might be responsible for impeding the enrollment of Native Hawaiians in engineering graduate studies and their academic/professional careers. The results will enable the development and implementation of interventions that will increase the numbers of Native Hawaiians in all academic levels of engineering. The broader impact of the project is the formation of a national Society for Native Hawaiian Engineers, which will be instrumental in disseminating the results of the efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We developed an integrated educational model for promoting Native Hawaiian graduate students toward academic careers, particularly as engineering professors. We developed products and publications for this project. The past and current work of the PIs Francis, Nyguen and Miller has facilitated research which understands the gaps in the matriculation from undergraduate to professor in engineering; created teaching and research experiences for students; and created a professional society, Society of Native Hawaiian Engineers (http://hawaiianengineers.com/) which is continuing the mentoring and networking after the project ends.

We identified the gaps between transformation from undergraduate to graduate and from PhD to engineering faculty. We gathered data from Native Hawaiian undergraduates, graduate, PhDs, and professors about their intent on pursuing a professorial career.  We found that more our graduate students learned of the possibility and what it entails, the less likely they were inclined to pursue academia over industry. Research is what drew the graduate students in, but the necessity of teaching and service were new ideas to them, which was a major gap in knowledge. Furthermore, we learned that the staunch hiring process of academia precludes our own Native Hawaiian engineering PhDs from teaching in Hawaii. The graduate program could transform to allow for exchange programs with sister institutions if academic mobility and inbreeding is a major concern.

We presented our results at the 2018 American Society for Engineering Education Conference in the Diversity Division, the 2018 Hawai‘i Educational Research Association Conference, the 2018 American Educational Research Association Conference in Division C: Learning and Instruction, Section 1e: Engineering and Computer Science Research; and the 42nd Annual Pacific Circle Consortium Conference. Our conference paper was also accepted by the 2020 Annual Meeting of the American Educational Research Association. The team is in the process of preparing three manuscripts for consideration in the Journal of Engineering Education and the Pacific-Asian Education Journal.

To facilitate teaching experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, PI Nygyen offered teaching workshops to the engineers and engineering students. PIs Francis and Miller offered teaching experiences in engineering by having NH graduate students give lectures for undergraduate engineering courses. This included CEE 320: Fluid Mechanics Fundamentals mentored by PI Oceana Francis and lab in mechanical engineering course ME 341: Manufacturing Processes mentored by PI Scott Miller. The NH graduate students were evaluated by the engineering undergraduates and feedback was provided. This included rating the instructor’s demonstrated knowledge of course content; if the instructor was well prepared for class; and the instructor overall. On a 5 point Likert scale, the NH graduate students rated between 4 to 5. To enrich research activities of Native Hawaiian students, NH graduate students were sent to national conferences and awarded research assistantships through NSF funding, which allowed them to continue their research under the mentorship of engineering professors.

To establish mentoring program for NH graduate students and a social network, we have established the Society of Native Hawaiian Engineers.  SNHE provides a national networking platform to connect NH scholars who are dedicated to advancing engineering education and research. This society facilitates the NH students to interact with other NH students and scholars, which will positively impact their and career development. As steps towards this goal, by-laws and a Board of Directors has been established.

We held two project summits in 2018 and 2019 for the Society of Native Hawaiian Engineers. In 2018, we convened two networking and brainstorming events and attended one engineering alumni mixer to promote and gather feedback on SNHE.  In 2019, we convened a three-day conference for SNHE. The first day was an engineering networking event; the second day featured notable speakers and two panels; and the third day was a working group session and election of Board of Directors and induction of new members.

To also establish a virtual social network, we have created a website. In the website, Society of Native Hawaiian Engineers (http://hawaiianengineers.com/), a major and important feature is the profiles of Native Hawaiian faculty, engineers, and engineering students. We are able to feature engineers in industry as well as up-and-coming engineers on the site and facilitate connecting them.
